Selective ring CH bonds activation of toluene over Fe/activated carbon catalyst Huihui Liu Guiying Li Changwei Hu ⁎ Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Technology, Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610064, China Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Technology, Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University Chengdu 610064 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 28 85411105; fax: +86 28 85411105. Graphical abstract Interaction between the benzene ring and activated carbon was responsible for the selective ring CH bonds activation. The carboxylic and lactonic groups on activated carbon played the role of ortho-positioning. Direct hydroxylation of toluene and related aromatics over Fe/activated carbon catalyst using hydrogen peroxide as oxidant in acetonitrile was studied. The catalysts were characterized by ICP-AES, N2 adsorption, FTIR, XPS and ion exchange experiment. It was found that iron was anchored on the surface of activated carbon forming iron carboxylate like species acting as active phase for toluene hydroxylation. 13.4% yield (TOF, 34.4×10−2 h−1) and 74.3% selectivity to cresols were obtained under the optimal conditions, and o-cresol was dominant with 56% selectivity. The interaction between benzene ring and activated carbon might be responsible for the selective ring CH bonds activation. The ortho-selectivity might be due to the synergetic effect by activated carbon and high-valent iron-oxo species. The structure of the key intermediate for the titled reaction was proposed and confirmed by theoretical modeling using Gaussian 09 program package. Keywords Ring CH bonds activation Ortho-selectivity Fe/activated carbon Cresols 1 Introduction For alkyl substituted benzene, side-chain CH bonds usually take the priority over those on the aromatic ring to be activated with the formation of benzaldehyde and benzoic acid [1,2]. The selective activation of aromatic ring CH bonds is presumed to occur where electrophilic catalytic species is generated in the oxidation of aromatic hydrocarbons [3–6]. The hydroxylation of aromatics is of considerable importance, for it involves the control of selectivity for the oxidation of aromatic ring CH bonds at the correct position. Cresols are important intermediates for fine chemicals, which are widely employed for preparing phenolic resins, antioxidants, insecticides, agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, herbicides, and dyes [7,8]. Generally, worldwide industrial production of cresols are done from toluene by multistep reaction processes such as sulfonated alkali fusion process [8], chlorinated hydrolysis process [8], cymene process [9], or by vapor phase methylation of phenol [10–13], and the obtained isomers are isolated by traditional distillation or crystallization [7,14]. Nevertheless, these processes bear some drawbacks like low cresols yield, low atom utilization with the production of byproducts, and apparatus corrosion. The vapor phase methylation of phenol requires expensive original material phenol with the high cost for separating cresols from the mixtures [7]. With enhanced atom efficiency, the one step hydroxylation of toluene to cresols under mild condition has attracted worldwide attention for it meets the green and sustainable chemistry demands, and it is one of the most challenging issues in catalysis research at present [7]. The search of heterogeneous catalysts is important, for the drawbacks involving low selectivity to target products and hard separation of products from the reaction mixtures containing catalysts in homogeneous processes could be overcome. The catalysts investigated in the oxidation of toluene to cresols are mostly transition metals supported on porous materials, such as TS-1 [15,16], vanadium based catalysts [7], Fe3+–Al2O3 [17], Fe-ZSM-5 [4,18], H[Al]-ZSM-5 [19], and so on. However, because of their high cost, multi-step preparation, relatively low catalytic activity, low selectivity or low reusability, they are used restrictedly in industrial applications. Fe species have been studied by many researchers due to their low cost. Compared to other supports like silica, alumina or magnesia, activated carbon has some advantages as support. The source of activated carbon is wide and cheap. The large surface area and high porosity of activated carbon contribute to the high dispersion of active phases. The nature and amount of surface oxygen groups can be controlled, and they can act as anchorage sites that interact with metallic phase improving its dispersion. Pilot study on the interaction between iron and the surface oxygen groups revealed the formation of iron carboxylate like species [20]. Previously, we studied primarily the selective oxidation of aromatics, and found the predominant ring oxidation and predominant selectivity to ortho-hydroxylated products, where a schematic coordination mode between the substrate and the iron species was proposed [21]. In the present work, Fe/activated carbon catalyst was studied in more detail in the hydroxylation of aromatics with emphasis on the selective activation of aromatic ring CH bonds and the prior ortho-regioselectivity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Commercially available coal-based activated carbon from Jiangsu Nantong Activated Carbon Cooperation (China) with a particle size of 40–80 mesh was washed by distilled water and then dried at 383K. The obtained sample (100g) was pretreated with 250ml 12M nitric acid solution at 363K for 10h in a 500ml round bottom flask, and then washed by boiled distilled water to reach a constant pH of about 7 and finally dried at 383K for 24h. The resultant sample was denoted as ACN. The Fe/activated carbon catalyst was prepared by wet impregnation method employing ethanol solution of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O with the concentration of 0.042mol/L, 0.084mol/L, 0.349mol/L, 0.698mol/L and 0.825mol/L. The impregnation was followed by washing with ethanol to eliminate the redundant Fe3+ and then drying at 383K for 24h. The resultant samples were denoted as Fe/ACN-a, Fe/ACN-b, Fe/ACN-c, Fe/ACN-d, and Fe/ACN-e. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 ICP-AES analysis IRIS Advantage ICP-AES was used to analyze the amount of metals on the catalysts. 0.03g sample was burnt up to ash at 1073K for 5h in air atmosphere. The obtained ash was dissolved in 1:1 (the volume ratio between distilled water and 37wt% hydrochloric acid) hydrochloric acid solution and further diluted to 100ml, and then the iron and sodium content could be obtained by analyzing the solution. 2.2.2 Nitrogen adsorption/desorption The BET surface area (S BET), the pore volume, and the average pore diameter (D avg) were measured by nitrogen adsorption isotherms at 77K using a Micrometritics TriStar 3020 instrument. The BET equation was applied to the N2 adsorption isotherms. The micropore volume (V mic), micropores surface area (S mic) and external surface area (S ext) were deduced using t-plot method. The pore size distribution was determined by the Density Functional Theory (DFT) method. Before measurement, the samples were evacuated at 373K for about 5h until a pressure of less than 10−2 Pa. 2.2.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS was used to provide information on the surface composition of the catalysts. XPS experiments were performed on a XSAM800 spectrometer (KRATOS) using Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV), the source being operated at 12kV and 12mA. The carbon 1s electron binding energy corresponding to graphitic carbon was referenced at 284.6eV for calibration [22]. The linear background was subtracted from all spectra. The software XPSPEAK41 was employed to deconvolve the XPS peaks, and the peak fitting was performed with 80/20 Lorentz–Gauss function. 2.2.4 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) FTIR was used to analyze toluene and cyclohexane adsorbed on ACN (ACN-toluene, ACN-cyclohexane). FTIR spectra were recorded in transmittance mode on a Thermo Nicolet NEXUS 670 FTIR spectrometer in the range of 4000–400cm−1 with a resolution of 4cm−1. 2.2.5 Ion exchange measurement To characterize the interaction between iron and activated carbon, ion exchange method was used. First, according to Boehm titration method [23–25], carboxylic, lactonic and phenolic groups could be differentiated by neutralization with the solution of NaHCO3, Na2CO3 and NaOH. In order to study the mode of iron connecting to the surface oxygen groups of ACN, ACN was respectively impregnated in the aqueous solutions of NaHCO3, Na2CO3 and NaOH with a concentration of about 0.25mol/L for 48h. The samples pretreated by alkali solutions were washed with acetonitrile to eliminate the redundant alkali, and then dried at 383K for 24h. The samples obtained were named as ACN-NaHCO3, ACN-Na2CO3 and ACN-NaOH. Second, ACN-NaHCO3, ACN-Na2CO3 and ACN-NaOH were impregnated by 0.084mol/L Fe(NO3)3 ethanol solution, and adequately washed by ethanol, and then dried at 383K for 24h. The samples were denoted as Fe/ACN-NaHCO3, Fe/ACN-Na2CO3 and Fe/ACN-NaOH respectively. Finally, ICP-AES was used to quantify the amount of iron and sodium on the above samples (as described in Section 2.2.1). 2.3 Activity test The hydroxylation of toluene was carried out in a two-necked round flask (50ml) equipped with a reflux condenser in water bath. 9.4mmol substrate was added to the acetonitrile solution with designed amount of catalyst. When the water bath temperature was constant, hydrogen peroxide aqueous solution (30wt%) was added into the reaction flask. The resulting mixture was refluxed for appointed time, and then cooled to room temperature. After filteration of the reaction mixture, the liquid products were analyzed quantitatively by GC (FILI, GC-9790 equipped with hydrogen flame detector and a capillary column AT. SE-54) using chlorobenzene as internal standard, and identified by GC–MS analyses (Agilent, 5973 Network 6890 N). The products included cresols, methyl-p-benzoquinone, salicylaldehyde, benzaldehyde and benzyl alcohol. The yields were calculated by the amount of product (mmol)/the amount of initial toluene (mmol). Selectivity was calculated by the amount of product (mmol)/the amount of all products (mmol), ignoring the ring-opening products, tar or polycondensed aromatic hydrocarbons because no such products were observed [26]. The selectivity of ring was calculated by the amount of ring oxidation products (mmol)/the amount of all products. Turnover Frequency (TOF) was calculated by the amount of product (mmol)/(iron contained in the catalyst×reaction time). The yield of cresols = The amount of cresols ( mmol ) The amount of initial toluene ( mmol ) The yield of methyl-p-benzoquinone = The amount of methyl-p-benzoquinone ( mmol ) The amount of initial toluene ( mmol ) The yield of salicylaldehyde = The amount of salicylaldehyde ( mmol ) The amount of initial toluene ( mmol ) The yield of benzaldehyde = The amount of benzaldehyde ( mmol ) The amount of initial toluene ( mmol ) The yield of benzyl alcohol = The amount of benzyl alcohol ( mmol ) The amount of initial toluene ( mmol ) The selectivity of product = The amount of product ( mmol ) The amount of all products ( mmol ) The selectivity of ring = The amount of ring oxidation products ( mmol ) The amount of all products Turnover frequency ( TOF ) = The amount of product ( mmol ) Iron contained in the catalyst × reaction time 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization 3.1.1 Nitrogen adsorption/desorption As shown in Table 1 , the iron content on the catalyst increased from 0.03 to 0.33mmol/g with the concentration of Fe(NO3)3 increased from 0 to 0.698mol/L, and then decreased to 0.30mmol/g when the concentration of Fe(NO3)3 increased to 0.825mol/L. It might be due to the limited surface oxygen groups on ACN which were the anchorage sites for iron. The N2 adsorption isotherms shown in Fig. 1 were corresponded to typical type I in the BDDT classification [27], which indicated that all the samples were micropore materials. The hysteresis loops in the nitrogen isotherm represented the existence of some mesoporosity, and the hysteresis loops of parallel adsorption and desorption branches was indicative of slit-shaped pores [28,29]. The pore size distribution of the samples shown in Fig. 2 also indicated that the catalysts were microporous with some mesoporosity. Table 1 summarized the porous structure of the catalysts. As shown in Table 1, with the increase of Fe content, S BET, S mic, S ext and V mic all decreased, but D avg increased. The results were most probably due to the consequence of pore blockage after deposition of iron on the mouth of small pores [30]. However, the extent in the decrease of S mic was larger than S ext, which resulted in the increased proportion of mesoporosity and the increase of D avg. As discussed above, iron was mostly loaded on the micropore [31]. 3.1.2 XPS characterization XPS was used to characterize the catalysts before and after impregnating iron. The C 1s peaks, O 1s peaks and Fe 2p peaks of catalysts are shown in Figs. 3–5 . High resolution XPS profiles of C 1s and O 1s exhibited asymmetric character, indicating the existence of different kinds of surface carbon and oxygen species on the catalysts. For the ACN sample, deconvolution of the C 1s spectra gave five peaks with different binding energies which represented [32–39]: graphitic carbon and CH groups (peak 1, 284.6eV), carbon presented in phenolic, alcohol, ether groups (peak 2, 285.6–285.9eV), carbonyl or quinine groups (peak 3, 287.4–287.7eV), carboxylic or lactonic groups (peak 4, 289.0eV), shake-up satellite peaks due to π–π* transitions in aromatic rings or carbon in carbonate groups and adsorbed CO and CO2 (peak 5, 290.6–291.0eV). For the surface oxygen species, the O 1s spectra fitted to five component peaks. The deconvoluted peaks at the binding energy of 530.3–530.4eV, 531.5–531.6eV, 532.8eV, 534.0eV and 536.0eV were ascribed to carbonyl or quinine (CO), carboxylic and lactonic groups (CO), COH and COC in alcohol and ether groups, carboxylic and lactonic groups (CO), chemisorbed oxygen and/or adsorbed water [34,36–39]. The results from C 1s and O 1s peaks illuminated that oxygen groups on activated carbon surface contained carboxylic groups, lactonic groups, phenolic groups, and carbonyl. After impregnating iron on ACN, there were some differences in the C 1s and O 1s peaks. Fe/ACN-b was analyzed as a typical sample. Compared to Fig. 3a of ACN catalyst, a new peak at 286.7eV (peak 6) appeared on Fe/ACN-b surface, as shown in Fig. 3c. This new peak was probably assigned to the presence of CO(Fe) species on the Fe/activated carbon surface [34]. As shown in O 1s spectra, the relative concentration of the peak at 534.0eV (49.4%) in Fig. 4a decreased to 30.4% in Fig. 4c after impregnation of iron. Thus, when iron was loaded on ACN, the content of carboxylic groups or lactonic groups decreased. A comparison of Fig. 4a with Fig. 4c showed that the relative concentration of the peak at about 531.5eV increased from 9.9% to 27.4%. Combined with the appearance of the new peak at 286.7eV corresponding to CO(Fe) species in C 1s peaks, this phenomenon was possibly caused by the formation of iron carboxylate like species [34,40] between the CO in carboxyl/the carboxyl from decomposed lactone and the loaded iron. Namely, because of the formation of CO(Fe) structure, the peak at 534.0eV shifted to lower binding energy (531.5eV). Furthermore, in the Fe 2p spectra, the signal of iron increased after loading iron on the ACN support. The presence of the main band centered at 711.8eV (Fe 2p3/2) was observed with a secondary one displaced 13.1eV to higher binding energy at 724.9eV (Fe 2p1/2), which corresponded to the characteristic values of Fe3+. The satellite peak around 719.6eV confirmed the presence of Fe3+ species on the surface of the catalysts [41,42]. The shoulder peak at 714.6eV might be ascribed to iron ions complexed with electronegative surface ligands [34]. Furthermore, the relative concentration of the peak 3 in the O 1s spectrum corresponded to CO in phenolic groups was changed slightly (38.2–38.7%). According to the above data, iron was mostly combined with CO in carboxylic and/or lactonic groups. In order to compare the variation of the relative concentration of surface carbon and oxygen species, renormalization of these species was made and the results are shown in Tables 2 and 3 . It was clear that with the increase of Fe loading from 0 to 0.27mmol/g, the relative concentration of carbon and oxygen of CO in phenolic, alcohol, ether groups and CO in carbonyl, quinine groups varied slightly, while that of carbon and oxygen in carboxylic and lactonic groups decreased drastically. Furthermore, the relative concentration of the new peak at 286.7eV increased from 0% to 11.6% with the loaded iron increased, while the oxygen at the position of 531.5eV also increased from 9.9% to 33.7%. This also confirmed that ferric species anchored on carboxylic and lactonic site, and the above discussion was in accordance with literature [34,43,44]. However, when the iron content increased from 0.27 to 0.33mmol/g, the relative concentration of the four carbon species was almost the same. The relative concentration of oxygen species corresponding to those centered at 531.5eV, 532.8eV and 534.0eV all decreased slightly, while the relative concentration of oxygen species at 530.4eV increased. The peak at 530.4eV might be also assigned to O 1s peak in Fe2O3 [45]. Thus, the excessive iron on the activated carbon might not combine with the surface oxygen groups, and exist in the form of Fe2O3. 3.2 Confirmation of the interaction between Fe and ACN Ion exchange experiment was carried out to further confirm the interaction between iron and activated carbon. The iron and sodium content of different samples were listed in Table 4 . The difference in iron content (D(Fe)), which indicated the iron content loaded on the ACN, was almost the same when ACN was pretreated with different alkali solutions. First, according to Boehm Titration principle [23–25], when ACN was treated by NaHCO3 solution, carboxylic groups on ACN were changed to sodium carboxylate. 0.23mmol/g iron content was obtained when ACN-NaHCO3 was impregnated with Fe(NO3)3 ethanol solution, and 0.13mmol/g Na+ in sodium carboxylate was exchanged by iron. Thus, there was 0.13mmol/g iron connected to carboxylic groups on ACN. Second, when ACN was treated by Na2CO3 solution, not only the carboxylic groups on ACN were changed to sodium carboxylate, but also the lactonic groups reacted with Na2CO3 to form sodium carboxylate. 0.27mmol/g Na+ in sodium carboxylate which was almost the same to iron content (0.21mmol/g) was exchanged by iron when ACN-Na2CO3 was impregnated with Fe(NO3)3 ethanol solution. Thus, iron also interacted with lactonic groups besides carboxylic groups, and all the iron on the support existed as iron carboxylate like species. Therefore, it could be seen that iron was just connected with carboxylic groups and carboxyl in the lactones on the ACN with about 1:1 as COO(Fe) [20]. This was consistent with the result of XPS. Finally, when ACN was treated by NaOH solution, carboxylic groups, lactonic groups and phenolic groups interacted with NaOH to form sodium carboxylate and sodium phenolate. However, when ACN-NaOH was impregnated with Fe(NO3)3 ethanol solution, the amount of exchanged Na+ (0.28mmol/g) was similar to the amount of exchanged Na+ (0.27mmol/g) displayed in the second part. It meant that iron did not connect with phenolic groups, which confirmed that iron just interacted with carboxylic groups and lactonic groups to form iron carboxylate like species. Thus, for the surface oxygen groups, carbonyl and phenolic groups did not interact with iron. Lactonic groups could decompose to carboxylic groups and phenolic groups, and the thus-formed carboxylic groups could react with iron to form the iron carboxylate like species, as the ACN surface intrinsical carboxylic groups did. 3.3 Catalytic activity 3.3.1 The influence of iron content on the activity In the hydroxylation of toluene, the main products were cresols, and the byproducts were methyl-p-benzoquinone, benzaldehyde, benzyl alcohol and salicylaldehyde. The catalytic activity of different catalysts is shown in Table 5 . Compared with ACN, higher yield of cresols was obtained over Fe/activated carbon. With the increase of iron content, the toluene conversion and the yield of cresols increased to the highest value firstly, and then decreased, and the corresponding TOF decreased monotonically. The performance of Fe/ACN-b catalyst with 0.18mmol/g iron content was the best, where the yield of 13.4% (TOF, 34.4×10−2 h−1) with 74.3% selectivity to cresols was obtained. Because the surface carboxylic and lactonic groups were limited, the excessive iron could not stably stay at ACN surface with higher iron concentration and could not exist as iron carboxylate like species. The excess of iron on the catalysts also resulted in the pore blockage accompanying the decrease of S BET. Thus, it was unfavorable to the formation of cresols with excessive iron on ACN. Moreover, we could see that it was favorable to obtain the ring CH bond activation products over ACN and Fe/activated carbon catalysts, and the selectivity of ring oxidation products reached to 83.7% and 84.8% with ACN and Fe/ACN-b. However, there was no favorable selectivity of ring oxidation products (54.7%) when Fe(NO3)3 was used as catalyst, and the yield of cresols was only 4.2% with TOF of 11.3×10−2 h−1. 3.3.2 Optimization of reaction parameters 3.3.2.1 The influence of the amount of catalyst The influence of the amount of the catalyst was listed in Table 6 . The TOF of cresols decreased monotonically with the increasing amount of catalyst, while there had decreasing tendency for side chain oxidation products. The preferential amount of catalyst was 0.4g Fe/ACN-b catalyst with the TOF of 34.4×10−2 h−1 to cresols. While for the yield of cresols, it increased from 11.7% to 13.4% with the amount of catalyst increased from 0.2 to 0.4g. However, there was apparently no advantage for the yield and selectivity to cresols when using excessive amount of catalyst from 0.4 to 0.6g. This might be due to two main reasons. First, it was probable that activated carbon promoted the decomposition of hydrogen oxidation [46]. Second, further oxidation of primary products (cresols) to methyl-p-benzoquinone might occur. Thus, the yield and selectivity to cresols decreased with the excessive amount of catalyst used. 3.3.2.2 The influence of the acetonitrile dosage Table 7 summarized the effect of solvent dosage on the catalytic hydroxylation of toluene over Fe/ACN-b catalyst. The amount of substrate toluene was fixed at 1.0ml in the reaction system. The yield and TOF to cresols firstly increased with increasing amount of solvent, and the optimal amount of acetonitrile for the highest yield of cresols 13.4% (TOF, 34.4×10−2 h−1) was 10.0ml. However, more acetonitrile dosage was disadvantageous for the formation of target products. The selectivity to cresols and the selectivity to ring oxidation changed slightly with acetonitrile dosage. It might be caused by the low concentration of substrate and oxidant with excessive amount of acetonitrile which slowed the reaction. When the amount of acetonitrile was too small, biphasic system may form, which decreased the interaction of the substrate with the catalyst, and this was unbeneficial to the formation of cresols. 3.3.2.3 The influence of molar ratio of H2O2/toluene The influence of molar ratio of H2O2/toluene was surveyed with five ratios from 3.1 to 7.3, and the results are shown in Table 8 . The yield of cresols increased from 9.6% to 13.4% first, and then decreased to 10.7% with increasing proportion of H2O2. The TOF of cresols showed the same variation trend as the yield of cresols. However, the selectivity to cresols and the selectivity to ring oxidation tended to decrease slightly monotonically. This performance might be due to the deep oxidation from ring oxidation products cresols to methyl-p-benzoquinone with the excessive amount of oxidant hydrogen peroxide. On the other hand, the increase of H2O2 led to the increase of H2O proportion which might make toluene conversion and the yield of cresols augmented [16]. However, excessive H2O could decrease the solubility of toluene accompanying less contact chance to catalysts, and then lower toluene conversion and the yield of cresols were obtained. 3.3.2.4 The influence of temperature The variation of the yield of cresols with reaction temperatures was studied, and the results were given in Table 9 . The optimized temperature was 313K under H2O2/toluene molar ratio of 5.2:1, 10ml acetonitrile as solvent, and 5h reaction time, where the yield and TOF of cresols were 13.4% and 34.4×10−2 h−1. The selectivity of both cresols and ring products decreased monotonically with the increase of temperature. The lower toluene conversion and yield of cresols at higher temperature might be due to the enhancement of H2O2 self-decomposition and deep oxidation of cresols, while the substrate might have some extent of loss [39]. Compared to ring oxidation products, side oxidation products of benzaldehyde and benzyl alcohol were increased monotonically with increasing reaction temperature, which resulted in the decrease of ring selectivity. 3.3.2.5 The influence of reaction time The effect of reaction time on the catalytic hydroxylation of toluene to cresols over Fe/ACN-b catalyst was investigated, and the results were listed in Table 10 . The TOF of cresols decreased monotonically, and other products had the same variation trend. However, the yield of cresols increased from 7.8% to 13.4% with the reaction time increased from 0.5 to 5h. Along with the further increase of reaction time, the yield decreased. The results indicated that the optimal reaction time was 5h. Longer reaction time might lead to deep oxidation of primary products (cresols) to methyl-p-benzoquinone, and then the selectivity to cresols decreased as shown in Table 10. 3.3.3 The stability of Fe/activated carbon catalyst The leaching of active metal component was an important parameter for the stability of heterogeneous catalysts. To examine the recyclability of the Fe/activated carbon catalysts in the hydroxylation of toluene, Fe/ACN-b was used in a continuous flow reactor. The results are shown in Fig. 6 . The yield of cresols increased in the first 16h, and then it became stable at about 15% based on H2O2 until 200h. The selectivity of cresols was about 90% based on H2O2. The Fe leaching was almost negligible after 200h reaction. The above results indicated that the Fe/activated carbon catalysts were stable enough for the target reaction. The above process optimization gave out the following optimal conditions: 0.4g Fe/ACN-b, 1.0ml toluene, 5.0ml hydrogen peroxide (30%), 10.0ml acetonitrile, 313K and 5h. The highest yield of 13.4% (TOF, 34.4×10−2 h−1) with the selectivity of 74.3% to cresols was obtained. The catalyst could be prepared easily, and exhibited stable activity for the hydroxylation of toluene under moderate conditions. 3.4 Study on the reaction mechanism 3.4.1 The mechanism of ring selectivity As the results shown in Table 5, the selectivity of ring products was larger than 80% in the hydroxylation of toluene, and 84.8% ring selectivity was obtained under the optimal conditions. There were ring and benzylic CH bonds in toluene. The bonding energy of CH on the benzene ring was about 435kJ/mol, which was quite higher than that of the CH bonds on the side chain (324kJ/mol) [47]. Ignoring the influence of other factors, the selectivity of ring products should be less than 62.5% theoretically considering the possibility to attack CH bond and CH bonding energy. Thus, it indicated that Fe/activated carbon catalyst was advantageous for the formation of ring CH bond activation products. As shown in Table 5, the ring selectivity was 83.7% over ACN. Thus, we could found that ACN and Fe/activated carbon catalysts had similar ring selectivity in the catalytic hydroxylation of toluene. However, when Fe(NO3)3 was used as catalyst, it was not advantageous for the formation of ring oxidation products with 54.7% ring selectivity and 4.2% yield of cresols. Therefore, the above results implied that the support activated carbon might play an important role in the selective catalytic hydroxylation reactions [48]. To prove the guess, a control experiment was carried out employing different substrates, such as benzene and cyclohexane. 22.5% benzene conversion over Fe/ACN-b was obtained, where the products were consisted of phenol (14.8%), dihydroxyl benzene (2.8%) and benzoquinone (4.9%), as shown in Table 11 . The conversion of cyclohexane was barely 3.0%, where the products comprised 1.6% cyclohexanol and 1.4% cyclohexanone. Although the CH bonding energy (394 KJ/mol [49]) in cyclohexane was lower than the CH bonding energy in benzene (435kJ/mol [49]). 3.0% cyclohexane conversion was equivalent to the yield of side CH bond activation products (2.5%) for toluene. It was indicated that substrates with benzene ring could be selectively hydroxylated to phenols over ACN and Fe/activated carbon catalyst, and then we hypothesized that activated carbon could activate the benzene ring in aromatic hydrocarbons in the reaction system. 3.4.2 FTIR characterization In order to identify the contribution of the support ACN in the catalytic process, an adsorption experiment was performed. ACN was evacuated at 373K, and then impregnated in toluene and cyclohexane at 313K to test the adsorption of toluene and cyclohexane. FTIR was used to analyze the ACN before and after adsorption. The FTIR spectra are shown in Fig. 7 . Compared the spectra of ACN-toluene and ACN, three new peaks at 729cm−1, 1540cm−1 and 1631cm−1 appeared in the IR spectra of ACN-toluene. The band located at 729cm−1 might be assigned to symmetrical out-of-plane bending vibration CH bonds on the benzene ring [50,51]. The two bands located at 1540cm−1 and 1631cm−1 were probably assigned to the toluene aromatic framework vibration (CC), which were induced from the toluene aromatic framework vibration at 1496cm−1 and 1604cm−1 shifting to higher wave number. The band at 1631cm−1 might be also assigned to carbon aromatic framework vibration (CC) on ACN [52,53]. Toluene aromatic framework vibration was affected by the carbon aromatic framework structure on ACN, which caused the shift of IR bond to the higher wave number at 1631cm−1. However, other vibrations of toluene was absent in the IR spectra of ACN-toluene. It might be due to the strong infrared absorption of ACN which covered the vibrations of toluene. When cyclohexane was adsorbed on ACN, there was no difference in the spectra of ACN-cyclohexane and ACN. Thus, the FTIR results indicated that the adsorption of toluene on ACN might be chemisorpotion. Combined with the results of dominant ring selectivity, the interaction between benzene ring and activated carbon might be responsible for the selective ring CH bonds activation. 3.4.3 Identification of active species Generally speaking, HO radical was the main active species, as previously reported [54–56]. If HO radicals were the main active species, side chain oxidation should be superior to the ring oxidation [57]. However, 84.8% ring selectivity was obtained in our reaction system. To investigate the main active species, a control experiment was carried out with additives in the reaction system. Radical capturers, tert-butyl alcohol and isopropyl alcohol, were added in the reaction system, and the results are shown in Table 12 . It could be seen that there were just slight decrease of the yield to cresols no matter 1.0mmol or 9.4mmol additives were added. Thus, the results revealed that HO radical was not the main active species for the hydroxylation of toluene over Fe/activated carbon catalyst. Meanwhile, high-valent iron-oxo complex was reported to be the active species [5,58–60]. When 2, 6-di-tert-butyl-4-methyl-phenol (BHT) was added in the reaction system, the yield of cresols decreased with increasing amount of BHT. The yield of cresols was 10.6% with 1.0mmol BHT and 4.6% with 9.4mmol BHT added. This performance might be due to the competing reaction of BHT with toluene. It was also reported that BHT might remove the high-valent iron-oxo complex [59]. High-valent iron-oxo complex could be reduced to low valence [61] with ascorbic acid that was disadvantageous for the formation of cresols. While with the addition of 1.0mmol ascorbic acid, the yield of cresols decreased also severely to 3.3%. Thus, we proposed that high-valent iron-oxo complex was the active species in the reaction. Hence, the hydroxylation reaction mechanism could be triggered by the formation of Fe (III) hydroperoxo species with the addition of H2O2, which could undergo heterolytic cleavage to afford an electrophilic, high-valent iron-oxo complex [5,58–60], and capable of hydroxylating toluene to cresols. 3.4.4 The origin of ortho-selectivity In generally, the major ring-hydroxylated product of toluene should be p-cresol [4,7,15,16]. However, as we could see from the results in Table 5, the Fe/activated carbon was favorable to get o-cresol with about 57% selectivity in cresols. This phenomenon was consistent with the results reported in Ref. [21]. The preferential ortho-selectivity was also observed in Ref. [62], where the hydroxylation was catalyzed by HPMo11V combined with Pd/C. Therefore, there should exist optimal structural parameters which favored the attack to the CH at ortho-position of methyl to obtain o-cresol. A schematic coordination mode between the substrate and the iron species was proposed in Ref. [21], which just included some substrates like benzoic acid, anisole, chlorobenzene, etc. The ortho-selectivity was explained by the coordination between electron-withdrawing group in substrate and iron species. However, the alkyl substituted benzene like toluene could not coordinate with iron species. Here, we proposed another intermediate for the selective formation of o-cresol. According to the chemisorption of toluene on ACN and the result of dominant o-cresol production, theoretical calculation was carried out to optimize the structural parameters. Theoretical calculation was implemented with the Gaussian 09 program package [63]. The geometry was optimized at B3LYP method, with 6-31++G(d, p) basis set for C, H and O atoms, and the SDD basis set for Fe atom. The proposed intermediate complex is shown in Fig. 8 . The curved sp2-hybridized carbon surfaces of ACN played an important role, which forced parallel interaction with benzene ring in toluene to form delocalized π bond structure. This stable structure could activate benzene ring, and then the CH bonds on the ring were further activated. Hydrogen bonding was formed between the oxygen in iron carboxylate like species and the methyl hydrogen of toluene. The carboxylic and lactonic groups played the role of orientating group which urged the methyl of toluene orientation to high-valent iron-oxo complex active species. This optimal structure led to the event that the ortho-position of methyl in toluene was preferential to be activated over the meta-position and para-position. Furthermore, some other substrates possessing electron-donating or electron-withdrawing substituent were used for hydroxylation over Fe/activated carbon. As shown in Table 13 , in spite of the increasing steric bulk of the alkyl substituent from toluene to tert-butyl benzene, the 2-tert-butylphenol was dominant in the hydroxylated products. For benzoic acid and nitrobenzene with meta-directing groups of electron-withdrawing substituent, the ortho-hydroxylated products were nearly the same as meta-hydroxylated products. Therefore, besides the activating/deactivating nature of the substituent groups, there existed an ortho-effect over Fe/activated carbon catalyst as shown in Fig. 8 with both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituent. 4 Conclusions Fe/activated carbon catalysts showed good catalytic performance for the direct hydroxylation of toluene to cresols by hydrogen peroxide under moderate conditions. Fe/activated carbon catalysts were reusable without any appreciable loss in activity and selectivity for 200h reaction time in the continuous flow reaction. The ferric species anchored at carboxylic groups and lactonic groups on activated carbon with the formation of iron carboxylate like species. High-valent iron-oxo complex was proposed to be the key intermediate for the hydroxylation of toluene. The support activated carbon could activate the benzene ring in aromatic hydrocarbons with the predominant ring selectivity. The oxidative competition among the three positions on the toluene ring was influenced not only by the electronic nature of the substituent groups, but also mostly by the ortho-effect of the catalyst. The carboxylic and lactonic groups on activated carbon played the role of ortho-positioning. Thus, the ortho-hydroxylated product was predominant in the hydroxylated products. coredata.dc:description: Direct hydroxylation of toluene and related aromatics over Fe/activated carbon catalyst using hydrogen peroxide as oxidant in acetonitrile was studied. The catalysts were characterized by ICP-AES, N2 adsorption, FTIR, XPS and ion exchange experiment. It was found that iron was anchored on the surface of activated carbon forming iron carboxylate like species acting as active phase for toluene hydroxylation. 13.4% yield (TOF, 34.4×10−2 h−1) and 74.3% selectivity to cresols were obtained under the optimal conditions, and o-cresol was dominant with 56% selectivity. The interaction between benzene ring and activated carbon might be responsible for the selective ring CH bonds activation. The ortho-selectivity might be due to the synergetic effect by activated carbon and high-valent iron-oxo species. The structure of the key intermediate for the titled reaction was proposed and confirmed by theoretical modeling using Gaussian 09 program package.
coredata.dc:title: Selective ring CH bonds activation of toluene over Fe/activated carbon catalyst
